author: David Anderson
title: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp admits he could see Red again like he did after THAT Chelsea penalty
text:
Sport Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp admits he could see Red again like he did after THAT Chelsea penalty The German mocked his touchline rage towards the fourth official during Chelsea draw but accepts the stress of the moment might mean a repeat Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jurgen Klopp responds to Jose Mourinho's dig Share this video     
Jurgen Klopp admits he cannot control his emotions on the touchline. 
The Liverpool manager said he was lucky to get away with bawling “Nobody can beat us” in the face of fourth ­official Neil Swarbrick when Simon Mignolet saved Diego Costa’s penalty in the 1-1 draw with Chelsea on Tuesday. 
Klopp, embarrassed by his outburst, is grateful to ­Swarbrick for not sending him to the stands. 
He says he tries hard to behave, but cannot promise he won’t lose it again in the heat of the moment. The Liverpool manager was lucky not to get sent to the stands... (Photo: Reuters) ...and it isn't the first time he has blown his top in the technical area (Photo: Magi Haroun/REX) 
“I can’t give a guarantee that it won’t happen again,” he said. “I could say now that it won’t, but that would be a lie. That’s why there are fines for it. If we go over the top, then give us a fine. It’s right that we should pay the penalty. 
"Managers are not by nature the kind of people who want to have a go at the referee.Do you think Arsene Wenger is a person who, when he sees the fourth official, wants to punch him? That’s not how he is and everybody knows it. 
"It happens because of the circumstances, not because of the personality. Pressure even makes the likes of mild-mannered Wenger act out, says Klopp (Photo: REUTERS) 
"Sometimes you can’t control yourself and you say things like, 'Nobody can beat us.’ I have never heard a more silly sentence, given that we’d lost the three previous matches. 
"And as for how I looked when saying it... I was lucky in the way the fourth official reacted and I hope he didn’t get into trouble because of it. His was the reaction of a human being.” 
Jose Mourinho claims ­Swarbrick’s leniency towards Klopp smacks of double standards, the Manchester United boss arguing that officials take a much tougher line with him. Klopp knows his "Nobody can beat us!" dig was daft considering recent results (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) 
Klopp is baffled by Mourinho’s latest dig at him, but says he does not have time to question the motives behind it. 
The German claimed that, while he enjoyed chatting to Chelsea boss Antonio Conte before and after Tuesday’s game, he is too busy to build a relationship with Mourinho. 
“Honestly, I have no time to think about things like this,” he said. “Why are we talking about other managers? If you want a positive story, I talked 10 minutes before the game to Antonio Conte and 10 minutes after the game to him and it was really interesting. Georginio Wijnaldum, who got the equaliser against Chelsea, trains on Thursday (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Something has blown James Milner's mind (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) A much more low-key Klopp watches the action (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Sadio Mane is back from Africa Cup of Nations duty... (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) ...as the Reds prepare for a trip to Hull — who drew at Old Trafford in midweek (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) 
“We don’t know each other but we have something to talk about. Pep Guardiola? We are not friends but we know each other, so we talk when we meet. 
“But you cannot have relationships like this with all managers. And if I don’t have one, there is not time to start having one.” 
Mourinho’s comments were backed up by former ref Dermot Gallagher, who said Klopp should have been censured. 
“What Klopp did on Tuesday was unacceptable,” said Gallagher. “It was something that had to be dealt with and it wasn’t dealt with. Klopp should have been removed, without doubt.” Like us on Facebook
